prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(5-4) in SMM J04135
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to observe the CO(5-4) line in the source SMM J04135.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a spectral setup with one baseband tuned to the redshifted CO(5-4) line (at a frequency = 149.83 GHz), which we expect has a line width of 400 km/s. For this baseband we select the widest possible band of 1875 MHz. We include a spectral averaging of 4 channels in order to reduce the data rate (the resulting spectral resolution of 3.9 km/s is sufficient for the expected broad line). The other three basebands are set as continuum with the 2 GHz wide bands.

The CO source has been measured to be 1.66" extended in one direction (unresolved along its minor axis). We request an angular resolution of 0.8" as this will allow us to map the distribution of the emission with about a SNR~12 per beam, if the line is as bright as we predict (S DeltaV=5.15 Jy km/s).

CO(5-4) LINE: We predict that the CO(5-4) line has a line luminosity of 7.5x10^10 K km/s pc^2 using typical values for the ratio between CO(1-0) and CO(5-4) of SMGs (e.g. Bothwell et al. 2013).The requested depth is set by the predicted line flux of the CO(5-4) line at 149.83 GHz, which is S DeltaV=5.15 Jy km/s. We request a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy/beam/100km/s. This would result in a SNR of 32 at the peak of the line if the source would be a point source. However, the emission is expected to be extended over at least two beams. The high SNR is also required to establish the line profile in order to study the dynamics of the gas.
CONTINUUM: The continuum emission is predicted to be 0.8 mJy at 150 GHz. If all the emission arise from only one source (the quasar's host galaxy or the companion galaxy), the SNR will be high. However, as we aim to measure if the continuum emission originates from both sources, it is important we have deep observations. At the sensitivity of 0.03 mJy, we would be able to detect a far-infrared luminosity of 5x10^11 Lsun (assuming a modified black body with T=30 K, beta=1.5). This limit is essential to be able to discriminate between star formation in the quasar's host and the companion galaxy. The estimated time will allow us to reach the desired sensitivity. The overheads estimated from the OT are standard.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(8-7) in SMMJ04135
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to observe the CO(8-7) line in the source SMM J04135.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a spectral setup with one baseband tuned to the redshifted CO(8-7) line (at a frequency = 239.67 GHz), which we expect has a line width of 400 km/s. For this baseband we select the widest possible band of 1875 MHz. We include a spectral averaging of 8 channels in order to reduce the data rate (the resulting spectral resolution of 4.9 km/s is sufficient for the expected broad line). The other three basebands are set as continuum with the 2 GHz wide bands.

The CO source has been measured to be 1.66" extended in one direction (unresolved along its minor axis). We request an angular resolution of 0.8" as this will allow us to map the distribution of the emission with about a SNR~12 per beam, if the line is as bright as we predict (S DeltaV=4.12 Jy km/s).

CO(8-7) LINE: We predict that the CO(8-7) line has a line luminosity of 2.3x10^10 K km/s pc^2 using typical values for the ratio between CO(1-0) and CO(8-7) of SMGs (e.g. Bothwell et al. 2013).The requested depth is set by the predicted line flux of the CO(8-7) line at 239.67 GHz, which is S DeltaV=4.12 Jy km/s. We request a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy/beam/100km/s. This would result in a SNR of 25 at the peak of the line if the source would be a point source. However, the emission is expected to be extended over at least two beams. The high SNR is also required to establish the line profile in order to study the dynamics of the gas.
CONTINUUM: The continuum emission is predicted to be 6.3 mJy at 240 GHz. If all the emission arise from only one source (the quasar's host galaxy or the companion galaxy), the SNR will be high. However, as we aim to measure if the continuum emission originates from both sources, it is important we have deep observations. At the sensitivity of 0.03 mJy, we would be able to detect a far-infrared luminosity of 2x10^11 Lsun (assuming a modified black body with T=30 K, beta=1.5). This limit is essential to be able to discriminate between star formation in the quasar's host and the companion galaxy. The estimated time will allow us to reach the desired sensitivity. The overheads estimated from the OT are standard.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Submm emission inn TXS0828
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to observe the 350 GHz submm emission in TXS0828+193.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a single continuum setup at 350 GHz. We select the widest possible band of 1875 MHz.

In the previous CO(3-2) observation the CO emission remained unresolved within the 5" beam. We request an angular resolution of 1" as this will allow us to directly compare the distribution of the submillimeter emission and the CO(3-2) emission.

CONTINUUM: The submillimeter continuum emission is predicted to be 0.12 mJy at 350 GHz (for Tdust=15 K and an estimated dust mass of 1x10^8 Msun; the calculation was done based on Wiklind et al. 2014). The requested rms is 0.4 mJy, which would result in SNR of 3 at the peak flux density. If the CO emission region is associated with a gas-rich satellite galaxy, the predicted flux density is 1.46 mJy (Tdust=35 K), thus we would get a SNR of 36 with the requested rms.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) emission in TXS0828
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to observe the CO(3-2) emission line in TXS0828+193.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a spectral setup with one baseband tuned to the redshifted CO(3-2) line (at a frequency = 96.83 GHz), which we expect has a line width of 300 km/s. For this baseband we select the widest possible band of 1875 MHz. We include a spectral averaging of 8 channels in order to reduce the data rate (the resulting spectral resolution of 12 km/s is sufficient for the expected broad line). The other three basebands are set as continuum with the 2 GHz wide bands.

In the previous CO(3-2) observation the CO emission remained unresolved within the 5" beam. We request an angular resolution of 1" as this will allow us to pinpoint the exact location of the emission and whether it comes from one or more component/source.

CO(3-2) LINE: Based on IRAM PdBI observations (Nesvadba et al. 2009) the CO(3-2) line has a line luminosity of 0x10^9 K km/s pc^2. The requested depth is set by the line flux of the CO(3-2) line at 96.83 GHz, which is S DeltaV=0.23 Jy km/s. We request a sensitivity of 0.1 mJy/beam/100km/s. This would result in a SNR of 7 at the peak of the line if the source would be a point source. This SNR is also required to establish the line profile in order to study the dynamics of the gas.
CONTINUUM: The continuum emission is predicted to be 0.5 mJy at 96. At the sensitivity of 0.007 mJy, we would be able to detect a far-infrared luminosity of 5x10^11 Lsun (assuming a modified black body with T=30 K, beta=1.5). This limit is essential to be able to distinguish between the two possible scenarios regarding the origin of the CO emission: whether it is a gas-rich satellite galaxy or a filament/cloud in the halo. We note that the overhead time is??? of the total time. The estimated time will allow us to reach the desired sensitivity. The overheads estimated from the OT are standard.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
